qas.question: What are often used to teach students Chinese characters?
What resembles an actual person's handwriting?

context: <a0_0>Regular script typefaces<a0_0/> are also commonly used, but not as common as Ming or sans-serif typefaces for body text. <a1_0>Regular script typefaces<a1_0/> are often used to teach students Chinese characters, and often aim to match the standard forms of the region where they are meant to be used. Most typefaces in the Song dynasty were regular script typefaces which resembled a particular person's handwriting (e.g. the <a2_0>handwriting of Ouyang Xun<a2_0/>, Yan Zhenqing, or Liu Gongquan), while most modern regular script typefaces tend toward anonymity and regularity.
